text:
David Kraning has watched his profits diminish and expenses go up at Video Stop, the last video rental store in Pocatello, Idaho. Recently, he knew he had to close. But he faced a dilemma: What would he do about his most loyal customer? Christina Cavanaugh, 35, has come to the shop three times a week for more than 15 years to pick out movies with her mother, Toni Cavanaugh. Christina is mostly nonverbal and has Down syndrome. Renting her favorite Disney DVDs has been a highlight of her weekly routine.

â€œIâ€™d talked to Toni about needing to close, and I could tell she was distraught about it,â€ said David, 47. â€œHer daughter doesnâ€™t handle change very well. Coming to the shop was a big part of her day.â€

David said he always looked forward to seeing the Cavanaughs in the store, and he didnâ€™t want to leave them in the lurch.

Advertisement

â€œTheyâ€™d been coming in for years,â€ he said. â€œThey were almost like family.â€

About a week before he permanently closed the shop on Feb. 1, David came up with a solution: Heâ€™d move about 200 DVDs into a corner of his K & B Kwik Stop convenience store next door so Christina could continue to rent movies.

â€œHer top favorites are Disneyâ€™s â€˜Mulanâ€™ and â€˜Hercules,â€™ and sometimes she mixes it up with â€˜Pinocchio,â€™â€ he said. â€œI wanted to keep that going for her.â€

David said he cleared out some space at the Kwik Stop, moved over some shelves from the video store, then selected about 50 Disney classics and 150 other popular titles to put on display. One of his employees nicknamed the miniature rental shop â€œChristinaâ€™s Corner.â€

â€œIt felt good to know that Toni could continue to bring Christina in,â€ he said. â€œI wanted to do something nice for them both. I knew there had probably been some struggles over the years.â€

Advertisement

Toni, 71, said when she saw the shelves filled with her daughterâ€™s favorite movies, she burst into tears.

â€œDavid said, â€˜Look, I want to show you something,â€™â€ she recalled of her first trip to the new rental spot in late January. â€œI was crying so hard that I could barely talk to thank him.â€

â€œDavid is such a humble person, and heâ€™s usually very quiet,â€ Toni added. â€œI had no idea heâ€™d been worrying about how closing the shop would affect Christina. I thought, â€˜My gosh â€” heâ€™s been losing money, but he came up with a plan just for my daughter?â€™ Who knew this guyâ€™s heart was so big?â€

David kept his movie rental shop going longer than most, even when the arrival of streaming services put a large dent in his profits.

Advertisement

â€œMy dad started it when I was in grade school, and it was a huge part of my life for many years,â€ he said. â€œBut last year, I realized I couldnâ€™t keep it going forever. I felt sad to close it, but I was losing money.â€

Since East Idaho News covered Davidâ€™s kindness toward the Cavanaughs, a few other former customers have stopped by to rent movies, David said. But none of them visit as often as Christina.

â€œShe usually comes in with Toni every Monday, Wednesday and Friday,â€ he said. â€œIâ€™ve tried to keep things looking about the same as they were, even though itâ€™s smaller.â€

Toni, a substitute teacher, said she brings Christina to the shop after picking her up in the afternoon at an adult special education center in Pocatello.

â€œShe loves her routine â€” weâ€™ll go to the video store, then have dinner and go to exercise class,â€ she said.

After her daughter selects a movie for the night, she takes it to the counter and pays the $1.05 rental fee, Toni said.

â€œIt helps with her life skills,â€ she said, noting that Christina reaches out with her hand to touch the salesclerk as a way to say thank you.

David said no words are needed.
title: Store owner relocates his shop for his best customer, a woman with Down syndrome

text:
A major fire erupted at a garbage dumping ground managed by the Noida Authority in Sector 32 on Wednesday evening, March 5. According to reports, strong winds fueled the flames, causing the fire to spread quickly and engulf the entire landfill. The incident led to traffic disruptions near nearby residential areas and along the MP-2 route. Many netizens took to social media, expressing concerns about the toxic air that filled the area. "Do resident of NOIDA know @noida_authority has been dumping cityâ€™s garbage in the middle of the town-sec-32 or so? The dump caught fire few hours ago. Toxic smoke from waste has engulfed the area. @CeoNoida must look in," a X user said. Noida Expressway Car Fire: Driver Jumps From Moving Car As It Engulfs in Flames (Watch Video).
Fire at Dumping Ground
Noida, Uttar Pradesh: A massive fire broke out at the Sector 32 dumping ground in Noida. Firefighters have been battling the blaze for over 6 hours, and it may take days to extinguish. Local residents are facing breathing difficulties pic.twitter.com/w6LGgxN0Ui â€” IANS (@ians_india) March 5, 2025
Blaze Engulfs Dumping Ground in Noida
Noida, Uttar Pradesh: A fire broke out at the dumping ground in Noida Sector 32, which falls under the jurisdiction of the Sector 24 police station. Fire brigade teams rushed to the spot and are working to extinguish the flames. pic.twitter.com/N1gop9KzY3 â€” IANS (@ians_india) March 5, 2025
Fire Still Burns Today

Toxic smoke from waste has engulfed the area. @CeoNoida must look in. pic.twitter.com/Od2iYWXOaW â€” Rahul Shrivastava (@Rahulshrivstv) March 5, 2025

The authorities thought it was a great idea to set up a garbage dumping ground in the middle of the cityâ€”and now it's on fire! This isn't just negligence; it's sheer irresponsibility.#fire#noida #garbagedump #garbagedumpfire @noida_authority @Noidatraffic @CeoNoida pic.twitter.com/bQ3ZhEU1VI â€” Bongboi (@Bongboi16) March 5, 2025
